Throughout this page's journey we have been consistent in not posting pictures that were not taken by one of us, but when we received Anshu's email, we knew we had to break protocol and publish this story. 

A Teach for India fellow, Anshu, had this to say:

"It was 8'o'clock in the morning when I was standing with my other three fellows from Teach for India, waiting for the morning assembly to start. We were standing at the back and looking at our girls. What we could discern from the back that the girls were shivering in the damp foggy cold. We went forward and ask our girls, "are you girls alright?" In a quivering voice, they answered, "Ma'am and Sir, it's very cold." It took us a moment realize that few of our girls don't have warmers. Some of them were wearing a pair of summer clothes under their school uniforms and some of them were wearing low-quality warmers that were pretty useless against the harsh cold.

This made us come up with an idea of a secret Santa, where each one us can become a secret Santa for these girls on this Christmas. We decided to create a fund and buy all girls thermals and warmers for winter. And this where we need your help!

There are 160 girls in our classes and we are now raising funds to place a bulk order. We need a little over Rs. 65k and we need your help in raising the required amount and making this a Merry Christmas for our girls!"

"The adventure started with buying a cake for a friend whose birthday it was. Another friend and I called him to join us, but he couldn't so we decided to go around town and celebrate without him. My friend had a couple of drinks and around 1:30 am, we began to crave coffee. We checked a few cafes but everything was closed so we decided to head down to the railway station. Halfway along the way, we changed our minds and turned around and that's when the police stopped us. We still hadn't touched the cake that we had bought. The policemen started questioning me and I, like a bumbling idiot, asked them why were they focusing on me when it was my friend who had had a few drinks. Next they asked for the details of the vehicle and I told them it belonged to me friend. Well, turns out it wasn't. He had borrowed his father's car. By now the inspector was adamant on calling our parents but we somehow managed to make them call our professor instead. He took his sweet time, it was late in the night and I was hungry. I had already created enough trouble for the day and I really did not want to create a scene so I snuck around and finally got to the cake when the inspector noticed me. By this time, even he was done with me and just as I was about to explain my situation, he said "Do whatever you want, but don't you dare open your mouth again!"
Nevertheless, I offered them cake."

" I take care of 350 dogs. I've lived here ever since they built PVR Anupam. I have all valid documents too. MCD officials can't just come in here and take my dogs without rhyme or reason. People come from far off places when they can't take care of their pets, they leave them with me. They say, "Amma will care for them". 
"How do you take care of all of them?"
"They are my kids so of course I'll take care of them. But it's not easy. I had a tea stall but that was demolished so now I scavenge. Someone sent in some clothes right now so that's good. The community, other animal lovers... they help. One person helped build the pakka wall over there in the back, someone donated rice, someone else sent in grains. That's how I can do what I do."

"Everyone has someone, someone they idolise... someone they respect, admire and emulate. M S Dhoni is my idol. His life, how he transformed from a regular simple man into a brand in himself is inspiring. Every time he saunters in for the toss before a match, he is asked about his strategy for the day and he always replies 'We want to keep things simple'. That's what I love about him. It's an excellent advice - to avoid complications and keep things simple. Apart from this, I've also learnt how to manage to finish things. Dhoni is often touted amongst the best finishers in cricketing history. Everyone knows how to start something but often, we just leave it halfway. It is from Dhoni that I've learnt the importance of finishing things and finishing them with a certain amount of dedicated and finesse. "

"How have you applied these things in your life?"

"Whenever I'm in an adverse situation and things aren't going my way, I remember Dhoni. I keep my nerves under control, I consciously keep tension at bay and remind myself of Dhoni's words... 'to keep things simple...' I just keep that in mind and it sees me through."

"हर किसी का कोई idol होता है लाइफ में जिसकी तरह वो बनना चाहता है। मैं भी वैसे ही M S Dhoni को अपना idol मानता हूँ। उनकी लाइफ, वो कैसे एक रेगुलर, छोटे से आदमी से अपने आप में एक ब्रांड बने. मुझे उनके बारे में सबसे अच्छी चीज़ ये लगती है जब भी मैच से पहले टॉस के लिए वो मैदान पर उतरते हैं तो उनसे पूछा जाता की आपकी strategy क्या है और धोनी का एक ही जवाब होता है कि 'We want to keep things simple.' मुझे उनकी ये बात बहुत अच्छी लगती है. देखा जाए तो लाइफ की बहुत अच्छी सीख है - की चीज़ों को complicate करने के बजाय आप उन्हें simple रखें। इसके अलावा मैंने उनसे काम को ख़त्म करना सीखा  है।  वो बेहतरीन finishers में से एक माने जाते हैं।  काम शुरू करना तो सब जानते हैं पर उसे ख़त्म करना और तरीके से ख़त्म करना मैंने उनसे सीखा है।"

"आपने धोनी से जो सीखा उसे अपनी लाइफ में कैसे अप्लाई करते हैं?"

"जब भी मैं किसी adverse सिचुएशन में होता हूँ और जैसा मैं चाहूँ वैसा नहीं हो रहा होता तो मैं धोनी को याद करता हूँ। अपनी nerves को कंट्रोल में रखता हूँ,
टेंशन नहीं लेता और उनके जो लफ्ज़ हैं वो खुदको याद दिलाता हूँ... 'to keep things simple...' और बस उसी को ख्याल में रख के काम करता हूँ।"

"I am super-gay and super out about it. It took me almost two years to come to terms with it and I came out to my parents just a couple of months ago. In fact, my sister was supercool about it... I think she probably knew it ever before I did. She asked me who I was dating and I ended up naming a random girl. But when I did tell her finally, she was extremely supportive."
"You said it took you a while to come to terms with it... so what was your moment of truth?"
"I spent a major part of my high-school being anxious and confused and finally towards the end of class 12, I realised I couldn't let this go on any longer. So I sat down and analysed everything and towards the end, I just knew. And once I came to terms with it, everything became easier. I felt free, I felt I finally understood things, I felt I could express myself freely.
In fact, I started writing a blog and all these people who used to bully me or avoid me... I became really good friends with them. I know that all the hate and discrimination is just a lack of awareness and things are changing. I'm very optimistic of the future now."

"Guys, can I take your picture?"
They look at each other with the apprehensiveness apparent on their faces but agree to let me take a photograph. I do.
"So, I'd like you guys to know that this is for a page I run... called Humans of New Delhi..."
Before I could even finish my sentence, an immediate change of mood has taken over. Hairclips and scrunchies go flying, hair comes undone as everybody intones, "Take a picture now!" Even as the girl on the right rolls her eyes and exclaims, "You guys!"

I also got some very important advice on making friends,

I saw him playing near the GK 2 M-Block market... I watched the kids play for a while and then walked on. I passed them again on my way back and he came running to me. He said brushed it off with a quick "Main jal gya tha (I got burnt)" and before I could ask anything else, he ran away as quickly as he had approached me. No questions about the photograph, not even a simple 'show me.' Nothing. Kids are mysterious creatures.

Edit: A few comments later, I realised that perhaps I failed in putting across the interaction effectively and hence this little note.

He didn't run away afraid or traumatised or uncomfortable. He ran away the same way he had run to me - with enthusiasm. He answered my question with absolute nonchalance and just gladly returned to what he was doing before he walked up to me. I did not leave the scene and neither did he. He just resumed playing across the road. That's all.

I'm not refuting your astute observation, nor am I denying the possibility that I may have made him uncomfortable. I wish I had a way of knowing whether or not I did, but unfortunately, that is not possible now. Equally unfair are the assumptions that have been made. I'm not claiming that I am completely free of blame. Of course not. In hindsight, I need not have asked him what I did, but I would like to point out that while I might have been an idiot, this kid is clearly too awesome to be bothered by the likes of me.

That's when I discovered the second pup! Badly wounded, and barely moving. I tried to soothe the dog, picked up the pups and carried them to safety. 

This is not a story about anybody's heroics. "Maula sab ki manokaamna poori kare!"

"Would you like to say something to a large group of people?"
"May Allah bless them all!"

"I live two lives. When I'm working, I'm entirely dedicated to my company, my job, my responsibilities. Life is work for me 24x7. But every once in a while when I do take a break, it's a clean break. I switch off my phone, I don't check e-mails... work doesn't exist for me in that oasis. I need that period of detachment to recharge myself and get in the game all rejuvenated."

"What is your greatest fear in life?"
"Losing my loved ones."
"Have you ever lost someone?"
"My father. I was pretty young when I lost him, but I couldn't risk getting adversely affected. I knew I had to keep it all together for my mother and my younger brother who looked up to me.
"How did that experience change you?"
"It taught me a great deal about strength and courage. I understood the importance of family, of a good support system and thankfully, I've been blessed. I have immense support from my family, my husband and his family. I have a fantastic circle of friends that I can depend on. I care for all the people in my life and I deeply value their presence."

"I'm from China. I'm here to study."
"What did you like most about India?"
"Mumbai."
"What is so awesome about Mumbai?"
"What isn't?"

"What is the happiest moment of your life?"
"The time I helped save a kid's life."
"What happened?"
"I saw a kid being hit by a vehicle and asked my driver to stop. We then picked him up and drove off to the nearest hospital. He was bleeding profusely so I was scared. Someone called the police and they traced the kid's family. I was with his father when the doctor finally pronounced him out of danger.
I feel there is a reason to everything. There was a reason why I was there at that exact moment. It had to happen, and i had to play my role. I'm just glad that I could make a difference."
"Have you ever felt like this some other time? That it is all ordained, everything has a purpose?"
"Just right now! I've been visiting the Book Fair for three days now and I had never entered this hall until I heard someone mention it. Then I noticed a stall I wanted to visit but instead of going towards it, I entered this alley. And I saw you pass me by but then you doubled back and asked me for my picture. So many things could've been different, but they weren't. I had to meet you today. Tell me if that wasn't ordained, then what was it?"

"What is the greatest struggle of your life?"
"Life itself"
"What makes you feel that?"
"It is the greatest challenge there is. You work really hard, and at the end of the day you feel you finally know something, that you've done something worthwhile, but then you wake up the next day and you realise that it was a delusion... you don't really know anything at all and a new struggle begins. It's a vicious circle."

"I'm an art professor but I was born very poor in USA where dark skin was considered as bad. Luckily, I got a good education, which was in itself a big deal at that time. I'm talking about years ago, of course; I'm 72 now. So I got lucky and got a master's degree in Art and landed a good job. My job is only 2 days a week. I've had a 5-day weekend for 43 years now."

"Who do you contribute your success to?"
"Ganesh has helped me make a difference in my life. He has helped me overcome great difficulties. That's what he does."

"Any thoughts on India?"
"I love this country because the spirit shines out here."

Early morning bliss!

It's a strange kind of feeling to have your work noticed. It's even stranger to have it written about in a national newspaper. Strange, but humbling.

Here's to all 3576 of you who have made this journey worthwhile and to many more who will hopefully join as we trod on!

Deccan Herald's feature on Humans of New Delhi - HOND in yesterday's paper.

"I come from a traditional family in Saharanpur. Back at home my passion was not taken seriously. There was a distinct lack of a support system. Nobody thought I could make it as a cartoonist. But I decided to take one last chance. Hopes intact, I left home and came to Delhi. What followed was a lot of struggle, but eventually I landed my first job in this industry. That's when I felt things could finally be alright."

HOND's Note: For those unaware, this is Faisal Bhai, creator of the notorious Guddu and Gang and the hilariously nostalgic Garbage Bin.
A few months ago we ran into this beautiful couple. Today, we just wanted to share their wonderful story again, for theirs is one remarkable tale.
It was my luck I ran into him in what was clearly the perfect light for the cosplay.

There was definitely magic in the air at the Comic Con. I stopped this kid for a picture. Managed to click this and as I was preparing to take another, I looked through the viewfinder only to notice that he had vanished!
Anybody recognise the cosplay?
We're really sorry our photos from the Delhi Comic Con are a little late, but they're here finally! Keep watching this space.

Boy was Comic Con crazy. We were almost crushed twice today! Planning to be smarter about it tomorrow. But who thinks logic when there's such excitement in the air! Nevertheless, look out for us tomorrow. Photos will follow soon!

It is days like this that we wonder if it's worth searching for humanity when this city time and again reminds us of the inhumane creatures thriving here. And yet, perhaps that's exactly why we need to to continue. To search for that proverbial needle in the haystack, because when there's nothing there's hope. Get well soon, Delhi. RIP Nido Taniam.

"लोग धर्म के, विश्वास के नाम पर यमुना में सिक्के फेंकते हैं और मैं एक चुंबक डाल के जो कुछ मिलता है उससे गुज़ारा करता हूँ| मेरे ३ बच्चे हैं और सिर्फ़ यही एक कमाई का ज़रिया है|"

"People throw coins in the Yamuna in the name of religion and belief. I throw in a magnet and make do with whatever I can salvage. I have three kids and this is my only source of income."

"I realised early on that handicraft was my passion, but it took a while to translate that into a situation where it was also my livelihood. It's not easy to find takers. There are those who appreciate it, but with easy and cheap alternatives available, not many seem drawn to the real thing. The numbers are dwindling."

"Music is my life"
"Are you a professional musician?"
"Yes, and I teach it as well. Both instrumental as well as musical."

(HOND's note: In case anyone's interested, just drop us a message. We have the gentleman's details.)

"Any resolutions this year?"
"Just one: Working hard."
"If you could give one advice to a large group of people, what would you say?"
"Work hard."

"I started sketching about 4 years ago, and now I'm trying to make my living with it."
"What's special about your sketches?"
"I don't sketch what I see. I sketch the mirror image."

I was walking by when I came across this interesting instrument just lying on the road. I could see that it was special to someone. Hand-made and well-worn; the instrument told its own story. I decided to wait out in the hope that some human might come to lay his claim to this beauty and it paid off. He did return!

"I carved it out of a pumpkin, a regular cane and used this piece of ivory to tie the string," he told me. I asked him if he played it too. That's when he broke into a beautiful folk melody in the traditional 'pahadi' style. We bonded over the music for a while, I took some photos and as I watched him play, I was reminded of a poet who once wrote about quiet bowers and things of beauty... 

"Therefore, on every morrow, are we wreathing
A flowery band to bind us to the earth,
Spite of despondence, of the inhuman dearth
Of noble natures, of the gloomy days,
Of all the unhealthy and o'er-darkened ways
Made for our searching: yes, in spite of all,
Some shape of beauty moves away the pall"
- John Keats, 'A Thing of Beauty'

"I'm meeting her after three years! We were in a boarding school together and have been friends for 7 years."
"What is the happiest moment of your life?"
"Last year on Diwali. It was also my birthday and for the first time in 20 years, I was with my family. I've stayed in hostels my entire life, so it was very special to celebrate the festival and my birthday with my loved ones. I even got a star named after me in the Aries constellation. Best gift ever!"

2013 marked the beginning of a dream project for us. And what a beginning it was! We discovered some interesting stories, and met many amazing people. But most importantly, we discovered you, our wonderful, supportive community! 

Team HOND would like to take this opportunity to wish each and every one of you a smashing New Year! 

(PS: Tell your friends about us, so that if we run into them, they are at least willing to hear us out. That has been our biggest challenge in 2013.)
"This year my only resolution is to stay rooted and to connect. There's so much about my own country that I don't know. It's time to fix that."

"The happiest moment of my life hasn't arrived yet, but I know it will soon."
"How does that work?"
"It's when my pension starts."
"But you're a coolie... What pension would you get?"
"(laughs) Oh I have a pension plan in place. I call it 'my son.' I worked all my life... carried weight for meagre sums of money but I managed to get him a good education. now he's got a job. Soon he'll start working. That's when I'll quit. That's the plan."

While the entire world celebrates the day with carols and tinsel and decorated Christmas Trees, the place next to my office celebrates with burglar Santas.

Merry Christmas, everyone!
"I don't care about how they form the government or who becomes the Chief Minister. Enough promises have been made and I just want to see development now. They better deliver."
"Come Christmas, and I just wish I could be a kid again. Those were the days."
"When there was nothing, He guided me. When all hope was lost, He saw me through. It's all about Him. He is all."

They were singing 'Hare Rama, Hare Krishna' at Janpath when I ran into them. Careful not to disturb, I just stood there waiting for them to finish the bhajan. Towards the end, the man in saffron finally spotted me. I pointed to my camera; he understood and nodded his assent. I clicked this and left even as they began yet another bhajan, clearly planning to continue for a while.
"It's all really simple. Prices increase because of our greed. people don't believe in simple living anymore and with luxury comes misery."

"Here's the way I will try to describe India if someone asked me.  Imagine your senses are a bunch of analog volume knobs.  Volume is used to describe sound but let's imagine you have volume knobs for your other senses as well.

India turns the volume up on all of them.  I feel that could help someone understand what it feels like to be there.  The smells, the density of people, the stares, the rickshaws, the saris/turbans/burqas, the flavors, the honking, the bells, the animals, the crazy driving, the temples, the smiles, the monkeys...everything is on full blast.  Imagine full blast in your head phones, then transfer that to your other senses."

Kyle Pennell describes his experience in India.

"What was the happiest moment of your life?"
"Retirement."
"What do you miss most about your job?"
"It gave me the opportunity to interact with a lot of influential people. My favourite of the lot was Rajiv Gandhi. During the Asian Games of 1982, there was an invitation scroll to be distributed to the participating countries' head. He was unable to explain to me the font he would prefer to be used in for the invitation. Finally, he told me that he wants a font that resembles Old English, very ornamental. You know, like the typeface of the title of The Statesman, the newspaper? He was traditional about little things like that.
During the closing ceremony of the same games, while entering the Jawahar Lal Nehru stadium, Buta Singh, who was the Chairman of the Asian Games Special Organizing Committee, said to me, "Dada, kahan gayab ho gaye tum? (Where did you vanish, dada?)"
One great memory of my life."

I am a retro runner. I run in reverse.

"I love women. I love portraying women. Animal beauty, too, is a very common element in my work. I love the interaction of the two and it reflects in my work. These two themes always find a way into my art."
"If you could give a message to a large group of people, what would you say?"
"Don't give up. See a lot of great work. Do some great work. Surround yourself with creativity. Learn from life. And never stop learning."

"I use reclaimed material from cycles, scooters, motorcycles to create these sculptures. In March, I created a huge tree. Keeping all that material suspended in air was the real task. You can find it in Select City Walk. As for this one, I'm almost done with it. This empty space right here is for its wings. It's the final piece of the puzzle."
"What is the one thing artists tend to ignore when it comes to creating sculptures?"
"Most artists get a little carried away, and while that does result in great art at times, it is important to keep the emotional value in mind. One key rule that I abide by is to keep my sculptures as close to life-size as possible... makes it easier for people to identify with it and that fetches some beautiful reactions. "

"What was the happiest moment of your life?"
"I don't know about the happiest, but there was a day when I felt my life had a purpose. I've been involved with a lot of rescue operations throughout the country, but there was a particular day when I was in the helicopter and helped save a lot of lives at Indira Point, the southernmost point of India. I went to bed knowing I had made a difference. For once, I found both pride and purpose in my existence."

Today's Supreme Court ruling is disheartening and shameful for a country that time and again lays claim on progress. It would seem that our judges do not understand the very word or the fact that we're living in 2013. As far is this ruling is concerned, it may as well have been the eighteenth century.
Today, India was denied equality.

"When I decided to start a street food stall, I knew it had to be kachodis. It's the most under-appreciated street food in Delhi. People think 'street food in Delhi' and go straight to samosas, golgappe, parathe, and bhel puri."

When I was not easily swayed and refused on the grounds that even I don't like kachodi, he offered me a plate on the house, "Trust me, you'll like it."
"But I don't like kachodis"
"That's because no one makes them right. Take my word, I've been in the business 25 years..."

And that's the story of how I had the best kachodis I've ever had.

"I've had him for the better part of my life. I bought him when I had my last kid. That was 37 years ago. Now it's a race between who goes first and I hope I win. The alternative is unimaginable."

And finally, the much awaited and duly appreciated, I present to you the magician himself - The Chaiwallah!

"I can't function without my morning tea. It's amazing just what one single cup of tea can do, how it instantly just wakes you up. What's more, I had to walk 30 minutes for this one. He's the only chaiwallah operational at 4 am here."

We didn't really talk for he refused to speak. He could, we established as much, but he refused to. So after a good 10 minutes of trying to get his permission for the photograph and him doing the typical Indian head-shake in response, I used the benefit of the doubt and clicked this anyway.

"She asked me out 12 years ago."
"And then?"
"I took my time... It's not that I was not interested, I was just not ready for a relationship. We were together in college. She was my best friend. She used to maintain a personal diary. Every once in a while, I'd steal it from her bag when she was not around, read everything she had written about me and then carefully sneak it back in. She never found out."
"So when did you finally agree to go out with her?"
"10 years ago. To the day. I took two years to say yes, and she was waiting. Never once did her faith in me waiver."

"कौन पीछे छूट गया ऐसा?"
"मैं अपनी बीवी से बहुत प्यार करता थ. कभी झगड़ा नहीं होता था हम दोनों में। बहुत अच्छा जीवन था… सब सुख थे। जब अपने म्यूजिक के लिए मुझे एम्स्टर्डम जाने का मौका मिला तो उसने बहुत कहा की मत जाओ ऐसे छोड़ के नहीं तो मैं मर जाउंगी। पर मैंने सोचा ये सब कहने की बातें हैं, कोई थोड़े न मरता है ऐसे! मैं चला गया… और वो सच-मुच मर गई।"

Translation:
"I used to live in Amsterdam. Now I sell flutes here."
"Why did you leave Amsterdam?"
"There was a time when I had everything. Life was good. But then I lost it all and returned here, After that, I never felt like going back or anywhere at all... In life, some things stay with you, others not so much. If the one thing that is the most precious to you is taken away, then it breaks the human spirit."

We started this page with a simple intention - to gain a new perspective. How many times have we passed an interesting human on the street and wondered what their story might be? It is very easy to see someone once and write them off as a stereotype in our heads, but that's not how the world functions. As this page progresses, so does our journey into imagining others complexly.

It has not been an easy journey. We have been threatened, we've been accosted, we have experienced hostility of the kind we didn't imagine existed; once my friend and collaborator on this project - Rajib - almost had his camera broken. But if anything it has only provoked us, driven us to take this further and while 18 days into the project might not seem like much, the change it has brought about in our lives is remarkable. 

We have learnt a great deal about ourselves, about our fellow humans of New Delhi, maybe even a little bit about humans in general, but most importantly, we have learnt the importance of staying open-minded, of accepting others as they are, of celebrating humanity.

So here's to all of you who have made this worthwhile and provided us the much-required impetus -
Thank you!

- Kriti
